## Neurological and Autoimmune Conditions
- Your history of seizures and current use of antiepileptic medications (Keppra, Clonazepam) is important. Studies have generally shown that COVID-19 vaccines are safe for people with epilepsy, and there is no significant increase in seizure frequency after vaccination. The mRNA vaccines are particularly noted as being relatively safer for patients with epilepsy compared to vector-based vaccines[2][5].

## Autoimmune Diseases
- You have diagnosed and undiagnosed autoimmune conditions, including Hidradenitis Suppurativa and symptoms suggesting another autoimmune issue (Episcleritis, joint pain, high ESR and CRP). While COVID-19 vaccines have been monitored for safety in various populations, there is no specific contraindication for individuals with autoimmune diseases. However, it's crucial to discuss your specific situation with your rheumatologist to ensure that any potential interactions or exacerbations of your autoimmune conditions are considered.

## Consultation with Healthcare Providers
- It is prudent to continue consulting with both your neurologist and rheumatologist. Your neurologist's recommendation to get vaccinated is likely based on the overall benefits of vaccination in preventing COVID-19, which can be severe, especially in individuals with underlying health conditions. Your rheumatologist can provide insights into how the vaccine might interact with your autoimmune conditions and current medications.

## Summary
- Opt for an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine (Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna) to minimize the risk of GBS.
- Continue to consult with your neurologist and rheumatologist to address any specific concerns related to your neurological and autoimmune conditions.
- The benefits of COVID-19 vaccination generally outweigh the risks, especially given your medical history and the potential severity of COVID-19.

By carefully considering these points and consulting with your healthcare providers, you can make an informed decision about COVID-19 vaccination that suits your health needs.

155.question: Medical professionals are calling my bf's symptoms panic attacks, but I'm convinced he needs a neurologist. They last 3-6 hours, occur on more than half of the days in a week, and are characterized by extreme anxiety and neurological symptoms such as loss of balance, slurred and slowed speech, mental confusion, memory loss, rapid eye saccades side to side, fainting, and vomiting.Background: He has a history of childhood abuse and neglect and in general hasn't seen doctors in his lifetime. Early 2021 - Symptoms begin: He started losing his balance and slurring his speech in the last year, usually either after something extremely stressful (covid and unemployment really got to him) combined with having a beer or two. I thought it was his alcohol tolerance changing with age, so I wasn't too worried. He had several bad falls because of this, broke his glasses twice, needed stitches, etc... stressful but not concerning.  June 2021 - Symptoms worsen: He finally got a job in April, he was super happy. It was a bit stressful and outside his field and had a huge learning curve, but he loved it. But he started losing his balance and slurring his speech more often, even when he hadn't had a drop of alcohol. He also started having full blown panic attacks, where he couldn't breathe, would vomit repeatedly, thought he was dying... I used grounding and breathing techniques to help him through July 2021 - Psychiatric emergency room: In early July, he couldn't keep food down for 6 days straight and alternated crying and panic attacks. The slurred speech and loss of balance continued. I took him to psychiatric emergency in my city where he was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder and put on a low dose (25mg) of seroquel/quetiapine. He was put on sick leave from his job. He was matched with a local psychiatrist, so switched him from seroquel to 50 mg lyrica (gabapentin pregabalin~~)~~ that eventually increased to 150mg. August 2021 - Regular emergency room: Worst night. After feeling suicidal for the first time in years, he suddenly crashed face first into our shoe rack. Busted his nose open, black eye, full shebang. He was on his back and semi conscious, and couldn't speak. No asymmetry in smile etc but 911 operator and ambulance both suspected a stroke. He got carried out on a stretcher, down the stairs, rushed to ER, and kept for 2 days. He doesn't remember any of this except waking up in the hospital (but he was conscious and speaking/attempting to speak). MRI negative for stroke, EEG negative for seizure, bloodwork normal. Given one dose of ativan, discharged, told it was "bad anxiety", and to keep seeing his psychiatrist. Sept 2021-present: medical incompetence??? : He saw his psychiatrist 3 days after he was released from the ER. Doc kept him on Lyrica 150 and said ER wasn't concerning since all tests were normal. Asks why bf doesn't want to go back to work yet/is reluctant to extend sick note. Doc refuses to put him on waitlists for therapy, other modalities at the psychiatric hospital, etc... because it's "not that bad". My bf quit his job last week, since he faints at least weekly, vomits 2-3 times a week, and gets these "panic attacks" every other day at least (we're currently on day 4 of a long storm). Second appointment was Tuesday. Doc decided to lower lyrica to 100mg (???) and prescribed Silexan, a lavender oil extract(?!?!?!) available from natural food stores. Not available to buy in my country. No pharmacist near us has heard of it. Doc still refuses to do anything else and outright refused ativan when my bf asked for it because it's "not serious enough". Next appointment is in over a month. Bf was on the floor half an hour ago and unable to get up. Where I'm stuck: We're stuck in a loop of "well, he has a doctor, so go see him" whenever we consult a nurse, ER, clinic, etc... and a doctor that isn't taking this seriously. We're in Canada (Quebec) with no family doctor and current doc and er won't refer to a neurologist. We've tried putting in a doctor change request but in a strained system it's not going through. I've reached out to work colleagues within mental health research and they can't help/shuttle him in anywhere. Bf is struggling with feeling suicidal/like a burden and I'm scared all the time

- The differential diagnosis for panic disorder includes ruling out medical conditions with similar presentations, such as endocrine conditions, cardiopulmonary diseases, and neurologic diseases. ### Need for Comprehensive Evaluation

156.question: My son- 2.5 year old M, 3 feet tall, 35 lbs, takes 1.5ml Keppra 2x/day- diagnosed with generalized epilepsy in December and taking keppra since then- had mri under sedation in Feb and found a significant Chiari malformation (normal cerebellar tonsils are 3-5 mm, his are 15)- they say the chiari and epilepsy are not related though it seems like quite a coincidence to me. Thoughts??
156.answer:
The presence of both Chiari malformation type 1 (CM1) and epilepsy in your son, although seemingly coincidental, can be understood through several points:

## Chiari Malformation and Epilepsy
- Chiari malformation type 1 is a condition where the cerebellar tonsils descend below the foramen magnum, which can cause various symptoms, but it is not typically associated with epilepsy directly. The primary symptoms of CM1 usually include neck pain, visual disturbances, swallowing difficulties, and other neurological issues rather than seizures[3ा।
- However, there are cases where patients with CM1 can experience seizures, but these are relatively rare. When seizures do occur, they are often part of a broader neurodevelopmental disorder that may include mental retardation, autism, and other somatic dysmorphisms[1].

## Distinguishing Between Seizures and Cerebellar Fits
- Children with CM1 can sometimes present with "cerebellar fits," which are episodes characterized by drop attacks, abnormal posturing, and respiratory compromise. These episodes can be mistaken for epileptic seizures but are actually due to brainstem dysfunction and compression of the medulla[5].

## Clinical Implications
- In your son's case, the fact that the medical team has stated that the Chiari malformation and epilepsy are not related suggests that the seizures are likely being managed as a separate condition. The MRI findings of a significant Chiari malformation (with cerebellar tonsils 15 mm below the foramen magnum) are noteworthy, but if the seizures are not attributed to the CM1, they are probably treating the epilepsy based on its own clinical presentation and response to antiepileptic medications like Keppra[1][3].

## Monitoring and Management
- It is crucial to continue monitoring both the Chiari malformation and the epilepsy independently. For the CM1, symptoms and any potential complications such as syringomyelia or other neurological issues need to be closely watched. For the epilepsy, adjusting medications based on seizure frequency and type will be important.
- Regular follow-ups with both neurology and neurosurgery specialists will help in managing both conditions effectively.

Given the complexity of these conditions, maintaining open communication with your son's healthcare providers to ensure that all aspects of his care are being addressed is essential.

Given your detailed history and the extensive medical evaluations you have undergone, here are some key points and potential considerations for your episodes of double vision (diplopia):

## Types of Diplopia
Your experience describes binocular diplopia, as the double vision occurs only when both eyes are open and disappears when one eye is closed. This suggests the issue is related to the alignment or coordination of your eyes rather than a problem within one eye itself[3][5].

## Possible Causes

### Neurological Conditions
Despite the ruling out of brain masses, scar tissue, and other serious neurological conditions, it is crucial to consider other neurological causes that might not have been fully explored:
- **Multiple Sclerosis (MS):** MS can cause intermittent symptoms, including double vision, due to damage to the nerves controlling eye movements[3][5].
- **Myasthenia Gravis:** This autoimmune disorder can cause muscle weakness, including the muscles controlling eye movements. It is worth re-evaluating, especially given your recent episode where the double vision was significantly worse[3][5].
- **Thyroid Dysfunction:** Although you mentioned other conditions were ruled out, Graves' disease or other thyroid disorders can affect eye muscles and cause diplopia[3].

### Eye Muscles and Alignment
- **Strabismus:** This condition, where the eyes are not correctly aligned, can cause binocular diplopia. It could be a recurring issue from your childhood concussions or other factors[3][5].
- **Convergence Insufficiency:** This condition involves the inability of the eyes to work together properly, which can lead to intermittent double vision[3].

### Other Factors
- **Previous Trauma:** Your history of minor concussions and a benzo overdose could potentially contribute to your symptoms, even if no immediate issues were noted at the time. These incidents might have caused subtle damage to the nerves or muscles controlling eye movement[1][5].
- **Vitamin D and Parathyroid Hormone:** While your vitamin D levels are now normal, it's interesting that the peripheral neuropathy returned. However, your parathyroid hormone levels are normal, which reduces the likelihood of a direct link between these and your diplopia.

## Observations and Next Steps

- **Pattern of Episodes:** The fact that episodes are more frequent during lower light months (September to April) and the recent severe episode suggest there might be an environmental or seasonal component to your condition.
- **Disorientation and Dizziness:** The feeling of mild disorientation and dizziness when moving during episodes indicates a possible issue with balance and coordination, which could be related to neurological or inner ear problems.
- **Recent Episode Characteristics:** The significant worsening of double vision in your recent episode, which improved with monocular vision, suggests a possible change or progression in the underlying condition.

### Recommendations
1. **Neurological Re-evaluation:** Given the complexity and intermittency of your symptoms, a thorough re-evaluation by a neurologist, possibly with additional tests such as EMG (electromyography) for muscle function or more detailed imaging studies, might be beneficial.
2. **Eye Specialist:** Consulting with an ophthalmologist or orthoptist who specializes in eye alignment and muscle problems could help identify any issues with strabismus or convergence insufficiency.
3. **Keep a Detailed Journal:** Continue documenting your episodes, including any triggers or factors that you notice might precede or exacerbate the double vision. This can help in identifying patterns or correlations that might have been missed.
4. **Consider Other Specialists:** If your symptoms persist or worsen, consulting with an endocrinologist to rule out any underlying hormonal imbalances or a neuro-otologist to assess for any inner ear issues could be helpful.

Given the ongoing nature of your symptoms and the recent worsening episode, it is important to continue seeking medical attention to ensure that no serious underlying condition is missed.

158.question: My little brother has random faint spells (or mini epileptic attacks, we are not sure). This walker/cage bungee cord contraption would have to be able to hold the sudden shock of 250 lbs of deadweight when he has his faint spells. While there isn't a specific walker or mobility aid that combines a cage, a harness, and a bungee cord system to catch and support an individual in case of a fall, there are several options and considerations you can explore to enhance your brother's safety and mobility:

## Bariatric Walkers and Rollators
You can consider using a bariatric walker or rollator, which are designed for individuals with higher weight capacities. These devices can provide stability and balance support, reducing the risk of falls. Bariatric walkers and rollators often come with features such as wide seats for resting, hand brakes for safety, and sometimes forearm supports to help maintain upright posture[4].

## Additional Safety Measures
To address the risk of falls during faint spells, you might need to combine a bariatric walker with other safety measures:
- **Use of a Seat:** Choose a rollator with a sturdy seat that can support your brother's weight. This way, if he feels a faint spell coming on, he can sit down quickly.
- **Assistive Accessories:** Consider using additional accessories like non-slip mats, grab bars, or other home modifications to reduce fall risks.
- **Supervision:** Always have someone accompany your brother during walks to provide immediate support if he experiences a faint spell.

## Customized Solutions
Given the specific needs of your brother, you may need to explore customized solutions. For example:
- **Consult a Healthcare Professional:** Discuss your brother's needs with his healthcare provider or a physical therapist who can recommend specialized mobility aids or modifications.
- **Custom Mobility Aids:** There are companies that create customized mobility aids. You might need to contact manufacturers or organizations that specialize in adaptive equipment to see if they can design something that meets your brother's unique requirements.

## Fall Protection Systems (Not Suitable for Personal Use)
While there are mobile fall protection systems designed for industrial use, such as those mentioned in the sources, these are not suitable for personal mobility aids. These systems are heavy, complex, and not intended for individual use in a home or walking context[2][5].

In summary, while a bariatric walker or rollator can provide significant support and stability, there is no single device that combines a cage, harness, and bungee cord to catch and support an individual in case of a fall. The best approach would be to use a combination of a sturdy bariatric walker, additional safety measures, and supervision to ensure your brother's safety during walks. Consulting with healthcare professionals and exploring customized solutions can also be beneficial.

159.question: 26f. 122lbs, 5'2". Never smoker, rare drinker. On medication (trokendi, fycompa, Yaz, pristiq, creon, Cymbalta, b12 injections, pepsid, abilify). History of epilepsy, migraines, chronic pancreatitis status post tp/ait.Went to ED for abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that was unremitting for weeks. Had abdominal CT that found incidental liver lesions. Followed up with an MRI with contrast. The below are the findings in my liver. Hpw should I interpret? Is it something to worry about?"There are multiple (at least 7) arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, which are hyperintense on T2 and without internal fat. The dominant lesion measures 1.8 cm and seen in segment 6 of the right lobe (29:67). A few other prominent lesions include 6 mm segment 6 (29:47), 8 mm segment 5 (29:40), and 3 mm segment 2 (29:30). No definite washout however the lesions appear to enhance less then background vessels on delayed phases, arguing against hemangioma.Multiple arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, largest measuring up to 1.8 cm in segment 6 of the right lobe. Imaging features suggest adenoma with the differential including focal nodular hyperplasia."
159.answer:
Given the findings from your MRI with contrast, here are some key points to help interpret the results and determine the level of concern:

## Arterially Enhancing Lesions
The presence of multiple arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of the liver indicates that these lesions receive their blood supply primarily from the hepatic artery, a characteristic shared by both benign and malignant liver tumors[4].

## Size and Distribution
- The largest lesion is 1.8 cm in segment 6 of the right lobe, with several smaller lesions scattered throughout the liver.
- The size range (from 3 mm to 1.8 cm) suggests a need for careful evaluation.

## Imaging Features
- **Hyperintense on T2**: This suggests that the lesions have high water content, which can be seen in various types of liver lesions.
- **Without internal fat**: This helps to rule out some benign lesions like hepatic adenomas with fat content.
- **No definite washout**: The absence of washout in the delayed phases makes hemangioma less likely, as hemangiomas typically match the blood pool enhancement in each phase[5].

## Differential Diagnosis
Based on the imaging features:
- **Adenoma**: This is suggested as a possible diagnosis. Adenomas are benign tumors that can show fast enhancement in the arterial phase and become isodense in the portal venous and equilibrium phases. However, they can have a risk of bleeding, especially if larger than 1 cm[4][5].
- **Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH)**: This is another differential diagnosis. FNH typically shows bright arterial phase enhancement except for a central scar and becomes isodense in the portal venous phase. Central scar enhancement may be visible on delayed phases[5].

## Clinical Implications
- Given your medical history, including epilepsy, migraines, and chronic pancreatitis, and the medications you are on (particularly hormonal contraceptives like Yaz), there is a potential increased risk for certain types of benign liver lesions such as adenomas or FNH.
- The absence of definite washout and the enhancement pattern argue against more aggressive lesions like hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) or metastases, which typically show rapid washout in the delayed phases[2][5].

## Next Steps
- **Follow-up Imaging**: Periodic imaging follow-up may be recommended to monitor the size and behavior of these lesions.
- **Clinical Correlation**: Your clinical history and ongoing symptoms should be correlated with the imaging findings to determine if any immediate action is needed.
- **Biopsy or Further Evaluation**: Depending on the clinical concern and the lesions' behavior over time, a biopsy or further diagnostic tests might be considered to confirm the nature of these lesions.

It is crucial to discuss these findings with your healthcare provider or a radiologist to get a comprehensive understanding and to plan the next steps in management.

160.question: Hello. This is about my wife who is 19F. Non smoker. Non vaper. No medical issues. No history of epilepsy in her family. I would like to highlight main parts of this inquiry. Not going into too much detail unless required by someone.My wife (19) first time pregnant had an emergency C section at 36 weeks due to breech. Baby passed away. She was fine. Had some headaches and after 6 days at home she felt blurry vision and after about 20 mins got her first seizure ever. MRI suggested some activity in the front part of her brain. But doctors couldn't pinpoint anything. It has been a month and half (or less) and she had no seizure but some strange observations I had about her: Very sensitive to light especially when very sleepy or waking up.She had blurry vision again but partially and in one eye. One day she had in both eyes.e become a deep sleeper and it becomes really hard to wake her up. She would sleep for about 7 to 9 hours and wake up only if we woke her up. When I discussed these observations with the doctor he told me to decrease dosage to 200mg per day. Almost 2 weeks now since lowering her dosage. She has developed this strange itching all over her body that prevents her from sleeping since 3 to 5 days. She also felt her hand vibrate or shake for 2 to 3 secs while sleeping. oday she said that she felt her whole right side of the body vibrate a little and after that her right arm. She seems normal for the most part. No slurred speech, just that she forgot some of the things before seizures and also her journey from home to hospital. So is she at risk of getting seizures again? I am too damn afraid. Even when she itches the whole bed vibrates the same way it did when she had her seizure and this thing keeps me on my toes at all times. I also read that the itching can be due to some neurological issues and I think it might be Multiple sclerosis??
160.answer:
Given your wife's situation and the observations you've described, here are some key points to consider:

## Seizure Risk
- Your wife was prescribed phenytoin after experiencing seizures, which were attributed to the spinal anesthesia from her C-section. The medication is intended to prevent further seizures. Since she has not had any seizures since starting the medication, it appears to be effective in that regard. However, the risk of seizures can still exist, especially if the dosage is adjusted or if the underlying cause is not fully understood. It is crucial to follow the doctor's instructions and monitor her condition closely[1][4].

## Side Effects of Phenytoin
- The itching she is experiencing could be a side effect of phenytoin. This medication can cause a variety of side effects, including skin rashes, hives, and other dermatological issues. The itching could also be related to other factors, but it is a common enough side effect to warrant discussion with her doctor[1][4].
- The vibration or shaking sensations in her hands or body could be related to the medication's neurological effects. Phenytoin can cause tremors, loss of coordination, and abnormal body movements, especially if the blood levels are not within the optimal range[1][4].

## Dosage Adjustment
- The doctor's decision to decrease the dosage from 300mg to 200mg per day may be an attempt to balance the efficacy of the medication with the side effects. However, any changes in dosage should be closely monitored to ensure that the seizures do not return and that the side effects are manageable[1].

## Multiple Sclerosis Concern
- While the itching and neurological symptoms could be concerning, there is currently no indication from the information provided that suggests Multiple Sclerosis (MS). The symptoms described are more in line with known side effects of phenytoin and the initial seizure activity attributed to the spinal anesthesia. If there are persistent or new neurological symptoms, it would be best to discuss these with her doctor to rule out any other conditions[1][4].

## Monitoring and Follow-Up
- It is important to keep a close eye on her symptoms and report any changes or new symptoms to her doctor. Regular follow-ups with her healthcare provider will help in adjusting the treatment plan as needed and ensuring that she remains safe and healthy.

## Pregnancy and Future Considerations
- If she becomes pregnant again in the future, it is crucial to note that phenytoin can have significant risks during pregnancy, including an increased risk of major congenital malformations and other adverse developmental outcomes. She should discuss any plans for future pregnancies with her doctor and consider folic acid supplementation as recommended[2][5].

Given the current situation, it is essential to continue monitoring her symptoms closely and to follow up with her doctor regularly to adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

161.question: Every so often I get these really weird sensations that feel somewhat neurological that I haven't a clue what they are since they seem so different from anything else I know of. I've been getting them occasionally for over a year now. 25F. I just had one now and it leaves me in such a weird state of mind afterwards.I feel somewhat floaty and dizzy currently, so please forgive me if this isn't constructed well.It begins as a tingling sensation? Like a shiver. That flushes through me. And I feel some kind of emotion that I can't describe, like dread or deja vu or some kind of combination of the two. I become hyperaware of my sorroundings, like reality has become more real? It's very abstract and weird, I know. I usually forget the specifics of these sensations; but I've written them down previously while experiencing them so I can repeat these now. Afterwards, accompanied by a light headache that goes away fairly quickly.(Very, very rarely I get migraines with a visual aura, but this experience is completely different.)I'm really dizzy/floaty this time around and I'm not sure why. It has been a while since it happened; I thought it had stopped happening. It passes after some time and doesn't seem to negatively affect me, though it's very difficult to maintain a conversation or writing while it's happening. I don't think I've ever been this dizzy thoughNo other diagnoses, no medication, or anything else. I don't know how long the shivering phase lasts, but I think its under a minute. The dizziness is fading a little now, and I think its been about 10 minutes, though I have a light headache.
161.answer:
The symptoms you are describing are complex and could be associated with several different conditions. Here are some possibilities to consider:

## Panic Attacks or Anxiety
Your description of a tingling sensation, feelings of dread or déjà vu, and hyperawareness of your surroundings, followed by dizziness and a light headache, could be indicative of a panic attack. Panic attacks often include physical symptoms such as tingling, chills, dizziness, and a feeling of being out of control, which align with some of the sensations you described[1][3][5].

## Neurological Conditions
Conditions like Multiple Sclerosis (MS) can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including tingling, numbness, and unusual sensory experiences. The "MS hug" and other sensory distortions described in MS patients could somewhat match your experience, although the specific combination of symptoms you mentioned is not typical for MS alone[2][5].

## Migraines or Other Neurological Episodes
While you mentioned that these sensations are different from your migraines with a visual aura, some people experience other types of migraines or neurological episodes that can cause tingling, dizziness, and altered states of awareness. These could be related to various neurological conditions that affect the brain's sensory processing[5].

## Dissociation
Dissociative experiences can involve feelings of detachment from one's body or surroundings, which might align with your description of feeling "floaty" and hyperaware. However, dissociation typically involves a disconnection from thoughts, feelings, or bodily sensations rather than an heightened awareness of them[4].

## Other Possible Causes
Other potential causes could include:
- **Peripheral Neuropathy**: Although this typically involves more persistent numbness and tingling, especially in the extremities, and is often associated with conditions like diabetes or vitamin deficiencies[1][3][5].
- **Hormonal or Metabolic Changes**: Hormonal fluctuations or metabolic issues could lead to temporary neurological symptoms, though these are less likely given the specific nature of your symptoms.
- **Stress and Fatigue**: High levels of stress and fatigue can sometimes manifest in unusual sensory experiences.

Given the complexity and variability of your symptoms, it would be advisable to consult a healthcare professional, such as a neurologist or a primary care physician, to rule out any underlying medical conditions. They can conduct a thorough evaluation, including a physical exam, medical history, and possibly some diagnostic tests to determine the cause of your symptoms.

The issues you're experiencing can be attributed to several factors related to your epilepsy management and the decision to stop and then restart your antiepileptic drugs (AEDs).

## Risk of Seizure Recurrence
Stopping AEDs after a period of seizure freedom is associated with a significant risk of seizure recurrence. Studies indicate that the risk of recurrence can be as high as 26-63% depending on the patient population and individual risk factors[3][5].

## Individual Risk Factors
Your history of epilepsy, including the presence of myoclonic seizures and a full-tonic seizure, suggests you may have a higher risk of recurrence. Factors that increase this risk include:
- Longer duration of epilepsy
- Presence of multiple seizure types (myoclonic and tonic-clonic)
- Certain epilepsy syndromes (though your specific syndrome is not explicitly mentioned, your history suggests it could be something like juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, which has a higher relapse risk)[1][3][5].

## EEG Findings
Your EEG results show some abnormalities that could be relevant:
- "Foyer de ralentissement localisé fronto-temporal bilatéral intermittent" translates to "localized intermittent slowing in the bilateral fronto-temporal regions." This indicates some abnormal brain activity, even though there are no clear epileptiform anomalies. This could suggest an underlying predisposition to seizures that was not fully controlled by medication[1].
- The absence of epileptiform anomalies does not rule out the risk of seizure recurrence, as these can sometimes be missed or not present at the time of the EEG.

## Medication Management
The abrupt change in your medication regimen and the inadequate transitioning between medications likely contributed to the recurrence of seizures. For example:
- Stopping Keppra and switching to a significantly lower dose of Lamotrigine (from 500mg of Keppra to 25mg of Lamotrigine) is a drastic change that may not have provided adequate seizure control.
- The lack of clear guidance on how to make this transition and the resulting adjustment period likely increased your risk of seizures[1][3].

## Mental Health Considerations
While your mental health issues, including depression and anxiety, are important, they are not directly causing the seizures but can be affected by the recurrence of seizures. The psychological impact of seizure recurrence can be significant, including effects on self-esteem, stigma, and overall quality of life[1][3][4].

## Recommendations
1. **Re-evaluate Medication Regimen**: Consult your neurologist to adjust your medication regimen to a dose and combination that provides better seizure control. Given your history, it may be advisable to continue a more effective dose of AEDs.
2. **Individualized Risk Assessment**: Use individualized prediction tools and thorough risk assessments to determine the best approach for your specific case.
3. **Gradual Medication Changes**: Ensure any changes to your medication are done gradually and under close medical supervision to minimize the risk of recurrence.
4. **Regular Follow-Up**: Regular follow-ups with your neurologist are crucial to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment plan as necessary.

By addressing these factors and working closely with your healthcare provider, you can better manage your epilepsy and reduce the risk of future seizures.

163.question: I, 16(AFAB)(Diagnosed with ASD, GAD, MMD, and ADHD, no physical conditions known, I don't take any medication or supplements whatsoever), have been consistently baffled by what keeps occuring. I have no idea where to look anymore, and this is honestly a last ditch effort to at least point me in the right direction.Starting when I was around 11 years old, periodically, I'd go through a "episode" of sorts where exactly half my body would become completely numb and it became difficult to communicate. I believe I received an MRI among a few other tests, but ultimately, the episode was over by the time I had arrived. The weirdest part is that it's exactly half, and that includes all of that half (no joke, half my tounge and nose too) will go completely numb. Sometimes I will get an extraordinary horrible headache during this that lasts about 5 hours, which makes me incredibly sensitive to any form of light or sound. Sometimes I am able to delay these episodes by doing breathing exercises, but ultimately it's only a delay, and I end up losing vision entirely for at least 15 minutes during this.I have no idea why this happens, as the circumstances are different every time. It seems to be entirely random and completely cripples me for at least 2 hours. I want to know what it is so I can research it and hopefully focus on preventing it, or at least lessening the effects.Any ideas?
163.answer:
Given your symptoms and the absence of any known physical conditions, it is crucial to consider several possibilities that could explain these episodes, especially in the context of your existing diagnoses of ASD, GAD, MDD, and ADHD.

## Functional Neurologic Disorder (FND)
One potential explanation is a Functional Neurologic Disorder (FND), formerly known as conversion disorder. This condition involves neurological symptoms that cannot be explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition, but are nonetheless real and cause significant distress. Symptoms can include numbness, loss of sensation, difficulty communicating, and other motor or sensory disturbances that cannot be deliberately controlled[2].

Your description of episodes where half your body becomes numb, including specific areas like half of your tongue and nose, and the loss of ability to communicate, aligns with some of the symptoms seen in FND. The episodes being triggered by various and seemingly random circumstances also fits with the unpredictable nature of FND.

## Anxiety and Stress-Related Episodes
Another possibility is that these episodes are related to your generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) and other psychological conditions. Stress and anxiety can trigger a range of physical symptoms, including numbness, headaches, and sensory sensitivities. The fact that you can sometimes delay these episodes with breathing exercises suggests a link to your anxiety levels[3].

## Complex Interplay with Existing Conditions
Given your diagnoses of ASD, ADHD, and MDD, it's also important to consider how these conditions might interact to produce these episodes. For instance, alexithymia (difficulty identifying one's own emotions), which is common in ASD, can lead to complex emotional regulation issues that might manifest physically. Additionally, the executive function deficits and sensory sensitivities associated with ASD and ADHD could contribute to the unique presentation of your symptoms[1][5].

## Further Medical Evaluation
While the above possibilities are plausible, it is essential to undergo a thorough medical evaluation to rule out any underlying neurological or physical conditions that might be causing these episodes. This could include:
- Repeat neurological exams
- Advanced imaging tests (e.g., MRI, EEG)
- Consultations with neurologists and psychologists

A comprehensive assessment can help distinguish between a functional neurologic disorder, an anxiety-related condition, or another underlying cause.

## Conclusion
Given the complexity of your symptoms and the potential interplay with your existing diagnoses, it is advisable to seek a multidisciplinary approach involving neurology, psychiatry, and psychology to determine the exact nature of these episodes and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Given your situation, here are some key points to consider:

## Diagnosis and Medications
- The neurologist has diagnosed you with motor tics and ADHD, rather than myoclonic epilepsy, as indicated by the normal EEG results. Motor tics are characterized by sudden, repetitive movements, which align with your symptoms of shoulder jerks and whole-body movements[1][4][5].

## Medications Prescribed
- **Tetrabenazine**: This is often used to treat chorea associated with Huntington's disease but can also be prescribed off-label for other movement disorders, including tics.
- **Clonidine**: This is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist commonly used to treat ADHD and tics. It can help reduce both ADHD symptoms and tic severity[3][4][5].
- **Clonazepam**: While this medication is indeed used to treat various seizure disorders, including myoclonic epilepsy, in your case, it has been prescribed for emergency situations to manage severe jerks or tics. Clonazepam can be effective in reducing acute tic episodes[5].

## Concerns About Epilepsy
- Since your EEG was fine, the neurologist has not found evidence to support a diagnosis of epilepsy. EEG is a primary diagnostic tool for epilepsy, and normal results suggest that your jerks are more likely related to motor tics rather than seizure activity[1][4].

## Monitoring and Follow-Up
- It is crucial to follow up with your neurologist to monitor the effectiveness of the prescribed medications and to adjust the treatment plan as necessary. If you experience any changes or worsening in your symptoms, you should inform your doctor promptly.

## Comprehensive Approach
- The management of tics and ADHD often involves a combination of medications and behavioral interventions. Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) and other behavioral therapies can be beneficial in managing tics alongside medication[1][4][5].

Given the normal EEG results and the specific medications prescribed, it appears that your neurologist has addressed your symptoms in the context of motor tics and ADHD rather than epilepsy. However, continuous monitoring and follow-up are essential to ensure the treatment plan is effective and to address any new or changing symptoms.

165.answer:
The side effect you're experiencing, often described as "air hunger" or a feeling of not getting enough air, is not a commonly listed side effect of Vyvanse or other ADHD medications, but it could be related to several factors:

## Anxiety and Stress
Vyvanse, like other stimulant medications, can cause anxiety and irritability, which might contribute to a sensation of air hunger or discomfort in breathing[1][4][5].

## Physiological Effects
Stimulants can increase heart rate and blood pressure, which may lead to feelings of tension or discomfort that could be misinterpreted as air hunger. Additionally, the dry mouth and dizziness associated with Vyvanse might exacerbate this sensation[1][4][5].

## Management Strategies

### Breathing Techniques
While you mentioned you are familiar with taking full breaths, practicing specific deep breathing exercises or yoga breathing techniques might help alleviate the feeling of air hunger.

### Hydration
Ensure you are well-hydrated, as dry mouth (a common side effect of Vyvanse) can sometimes be interpreted as a need for more oxygen[1][4].

Discuss your symptoms with your psychiatrist. If the air hunger is severe or persists, it might be necessary to adjust the dosage of Vyvanse or consider switching to a different medication. Your psychiatrist may also recommend a different timing for taking the medication to see if it reduces the side effects[1][4][5].

### Addressing Nausea
Given that yawning helps temporarily but can lead to nausea, try to manage nausea with small, frequent meals and avoid heavy meals. Ginger or other anti-nausea remedies might also be helpful[1][4].

### Consult Your Healthcare Provider
It's crucial to inform your psychiatrist about this specific side effect, as it may indicate a need to reassess your medication regimen. They can provide personalized advice and monitor you closely for any other side effects that may arise.

## Long-term Expectations
Many side effects of Vyvanse, including those related to anxiety and physiological changes, can be temporary and may reduce as your body adjusts to the medication. However, if the side effects persist or become unbearable, it is important to discuss alternatives with your healthcare provider[1][4][5].

166.question: Hi. I just wanna have some guidance in advance if someone can help me :(This hadn't happened to me since March 2020. Back then I went to the ER and they couldn't find anything. Since it never happened again I didn't go see a neurologist but the other day it happened twice so I immediately booked an appointment.
166.answer:
Based on the symptoms you described, it appears you may be experiencing focal seizures, which are characterized by abnormal electrical activity in a limited area of the brain. Here are some key points to consider:

## Symptoms
- **Aura**: You mentioned seeing an aura, described as static that turned into colors in your right eye. This is a common precursor to a focal seizure, often referred to as an "aura" or "warning" sign[5].
- **Visual Disturbances**: The loss of peripheral vision in your right eye and the colorful static are indicative of focal seizures affecting the visual cortex[1][5].
- **Deja Vu**: The sensation of deja vu is another common symptom of focal seizures, particularly those originating in the temporal lobe[1][5].
- **Motor Symptoms**: Your limbs going cold, difficulty speaking, and the potential loss of consciousness are all consistent with focal seizures. In your previous episode, the rapid eye movement and droopy face also align with these seizures[1][5].
- **Other Sensations**: Nausea, cold limbs, and other abnormal sensations are typical of focal seizures affecting different areas of the brain[1][3].

## Types of Focal Seizures
- **Focal Aware Seizures**: You were conscious and somewhat aware of your surroundings during the seizure, which is characteristic of focal aware seizures[5].
- **Focal Impaired Awareness Seizures**: Although you were mostly aware, the difficulty in speaking and the near loss of consciousness suggest elements of impaired awareness, which can occur in more severe focal seizures[1][5].

## Causes and Diagnosis
- Focal seizures can be caused by various factors, including brain injury, stroke, infection, tumors, or genetic predispositions. Given your history, it is crucial to undergo a thorough medical evaluation[1][3].
- Diagnostic tests such as an electroencephalogram (EEG), CT or MRI scans, and blood and urine tests can help determine the cause and location of the seizures in your brain[1][3].

## Next Steps
- Since you have booked an appointment with a neurologist, it is important to provide detailed information about your symptoms and any previous episodes.
- Be prepared for a comprehensive assessment, including a physical exam, EEG, and possibly imaging tests like CT or MRI scans to identify any structural abnormalities in the brain.
- The neurologist will help determine the best course of treatment, which could include medications, lifestyle changes, or other interventions to manage and prevent future seizures.

Given the recurrence of these symptoms, it is essential to follow through with your neurologist appointment to receive a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

167.answer:
The symptoms you are describing share some characteristics with non-epileptic seizures (NES), particularly those of psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES), but there are also some other factors to consider.

### Characteristics of Non-Epileptic Seizures (NES)
- NES are often associated with mental health issues such as anxiety, stress, or emotional conflicts. They can manifest as seizure-like activity without any abnormal electrical activity in the brain[1][5].
- Symptoms can include loss of or change in physical function, such as numbness, tingling, fatigue, pain, headache, poor concentration, memory problems, poor sleep, and blurred vision. Panic attacks, depersonalization, and trembling are also common[1][5].
- Your symptoms, such as panic attacks, depersonalization, trembling, ptosis, and blurry vision, especially triggered by emotional stress or specific food intolerances, align with some characteristics of NES.

### Other Considerations

- Treatment may involve a combination of psychological therapy (such as counselling or psychotherapy) to address anxiety and stress, as well as management of any underlying gastrointestinal issues[1][5].

### Differential Diagnosis

In summary, while your symptoms share some characteristics with NES, a thorough medical evaluation is necessary to understand the full scope of your condition and to develop an appropriate treatment plan.

168.question: So I was diagnosed with Epilepsy last August and put on Keppra 1000mg twice a day. I did not like how it made me feel, so they moved it to once a day. Still, at times I feel foggy....seeming almost drunk. I was wondering if this is normal or maybe I was taking it at the wrong time of day. Should I take with food? Should I take before bed? I am not on any other meds except Motrin 800 for fake hip. Please let me know what you would recommend. Thank you in advance. I am a 41 year old male, 190 pounds and not a smoker.
168.answer:
The side effects you are experiencing, such as feeling foggy or almost drunk, are not uncommon for patients taking Keppra (levetiracetam), especially during the initial adjustment period.

### Common Side Effects
- Dizziness, drowsiness, and weakness are among the most common side effects of Keppra, particularly in the first few weeks of treatment[1][2][5].
- These symptoms can be more pronounced if the medication is not well-tolerated or if the dose is too high.

### Timing and Administration
- **Taking with Food**: There is no specific recommendation that Keppra must be taken with food, but taking it with food might help reduce gastrointestinal side effects such as nausea. However, it is not likely to significantly impact the foggy or drunk feeling you are experiencing[2][4].
- **Taking Before Bed**: Taking Keppra before bed might help minimize the impact of drowsiness during the day, but it may not address the underlying issue of feeling foggy or disoriented. It's important to discuss the timing with your healthcare provider to find the best schedule for your lifestyle and to minimize side effects[2][4].

### Adjusting Your Regimen
- Since you have already adjusted from twice a day to once a day and still experience side effects, it might be worth discussing further adjustments with your doctor. Here are some points to consider:
  - **Dose Adjustment**: Your doctor may consider reducing the dose to see if it alleviates the side effects while still providing adequate seizure control[2][4].
  - **Monitoring**: Regular monitoring by your healthcare provider can help determine if the side effects are related to the dosage or timing of the medication[1][5].

### Additional Considerations
- **Coordination Difficulties**: Keppra can cause coordination difficulties, such as ataxia or abnormal gait, which might contribute to the feeling of being foggy or disoriented. If you experience these symptoms, it is crucial to inform your doctor[1].
- **Avoiding Alcohol**: While there are no known interactions between alcohol and Keppra, consuming alcohol can worsen side effects like dizziness and sleepiness and may increase the risk of seizures[2].

### Recommendations
- **Consult Your Doctor**: It is essential to discuss your specific side effects with your healthcare provider. They can provide personalized advice on whether the timing of your medication needs to be adjusted or if a different dosage is necessary.
- **Keep a Symptom Journal**: Keeping track of when you take your medication and when you experience side effects can help your doctor understand the pattern and make informed decisions.
- **Follow-Up Care**: Regular follow-up appointments will help your doctor assess the effectiveness of the medication and manage any side effects.

By working closely with your healthcare provider, you can find a balance that minimizes side effects while maintaining effective seizure control.

169.question: Age - 30   Sex - male    Height - 5'8"-174 cm    Weight - 60 kgs.    Duration of complaint - 3 years    Location - Soft palate    Any existing relevant medical issues - Subjective Tinnitus caused by olanzapine and an MRI scan   Current medications - Cinolazepam for sleep, Mysoline for the myoclonus. Is palatal myoclonus treatable?
169.answer:
Palatal myoclonus, characterized by involuntary contractions of the soft palate muscles, is indeed treatable, although the effectiveness and choice of treatment can vary.

## Botulinum Toxin Injections
One of the most effective and minimally invasive treatments for palatal myoclonus is the use of botulinum toxin injections, specifically OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox). This method involves injecting botulinum toxin into the tensor veli palatini muscle, which can significantly reduce or eliminate the involuntary contractions and associated symptoms like pulsatile tinnitus. Studies have shown that this treatment provides reproducible benefits, although it may require dose titration to minimize side effects such as dysphagia, velopharyngeal insufficiency, and local irritation[1][5].

## Medications
Other treatment options include medications such as:
- **Benzodiazepines**: Clonazepam, which you are already taking, can help reduce the dysfunctional movements by its GABA agonistic properties[5].
- **Anticonvulsants**: Sodium valproate and piracetam have also been used to treat palatal myoclonus, although their effectiveness can vary[3][5].

## Additional Measures
Some patients may benefit from simpler maneuvers or devices, such as:
- **Sensory tricks**: Actions like pushing the palate with the thumb, wide mouth opening, or performing the Valsalva maneuver can temporarily reduce the movements.
- **Dental devices**: Acrylic plates may help improve phonetics and oral motor function[5].

## Considerations
Given your current medications (clonazepam for sleep and Mysoline for myoclonus) and the side effects associated with olanzapine (subjective tinnitus), it might be beneficial to discuss the option of botulinum toxin injections with your healthcare provider. This could offer a more targeted approach to managing your palatal myoclonus while potentially reducing the reliance on other medications that may have unwanted side effects[1][3][5].

## Monitoring and Follow-Up
Regular follow-up and monitoring are crucial to adjust the treatment plan as needed, especially if you decide to proceed with botulinum toxin injections, to ensure optimal results and minimize any adverse effects.

To address your concerns about the cancer risk associated with the CT scans you underwent, here are some key points to consider:

## Radiation Dose from CT Scans
- Each CT scan exposes you to a certain amount of ionizing radiation, measured in millisieverts (mSv). The doses from your scans are as follows:
  - Head scans: typically around 1-2 mSv each, but your specific doses were higher due to the DLP (Dose Length Product) values provided (e.g., 1005.29, 799, 763, 881.17 mGy.cm). However, converting DLP to effective dose is complex and generally results in a dose range of about 1-5 mSv per head scan[4][5].
  - Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis scans: these typically range from 5-10 mSv each. Your specific scans had DLP values that translate to effective doses in this range (e.g., 652, 1291.11 mGy.cm)[4][5].

## Cumulative Radiation Exposure
- Your cumulative exposure from the 7 CT scans would be estimated to be in the range of 20-50 mSv, depending on the exact conversion of DLP to effective dose. For perspective, the average person receives about 3 mSv per year from natural background radiation[4][5].

## Cancer Risk
- Studies indicate that while there is a risk of cancer associated with ionizing radiation from CT scans, this risk is generally low. The linear-no-threshold (LNT) model suggests that any amount of radiation increases cancer risk, but the actual risk at low doses is difficult to quantify precisely. However, it is estimated that the risk of developing a fatal cancer from a single CT scan is about 1 in 2,000[4][5].
- For multiple scans, the risk increases but remains relatively low. A cumulative dose of up to 100 mSv (approximately 10 scans) still results in a low overall risk of cancer[5].

## Comparison to Other Groups
- **Radiation Workers**: These individuals are exposed to higher levels of radiation over their careers, often exceeding 100 mSv per year. Your exposure is significantly lower than what radiation workers would accumulate in a single year.
- **Patients Treated with Radiation Therapy**: These patients receive much higher doses of radiation, often in the range of several thousand mSv, which is orders of magnitude higher than your cumulative exposure.
- **Pilots**: Commercial airline pilots receive about 2-5 mSv per year from cosmic radiation. Your cumulative exposure from the CT scans is comparable to a few years of a pilot's exposure.
- **Survivors of Erratic Radiation Exposure**: These individuals often receive much higher and more acute doses of radiation, far exceeding what you were exposed to.

## Conclusion
Given the data and the context, your worries about cancer risk from the CT scans, while understandable, are relatively irrational compared to the actual low risk involved. Here are some key takeaways:
- The benefits of the CT scans in diagnosing and managing your health conditions likely outweigh the risks associated with the radiation exposure.
- Your cumulative exposure, while higher than average due to the number of scans, is still within the low-risk range.
- It is important to keep a record of your radiation exposure, as suggested, but in your case, the exposure levels do not indicate a significant cancer risk[4].

Moving forward, it is crucial to follow up with your healthcare providers and ensure that any future imaging is justified and optimized to minimize radiation exposure. However, based on the current evidence, your exposure does not significantly elevate your cancer risk.

172.question: Suddenly, everywhere I look, people are touting the benefits of stimulating the vagus nerve. What is the vagus nerve, and what does it actually do? Does stimulating it actually have all these positive effects people claim? (Stimulating digestion, lowering blood pressure, helping anxiety, etc.) 35/F/white/115 pounds/sertraline/Canada. Is stimulating the vagus nerve bullshit?
172.answer:
The vagus nerve, also known as cranial nerve 10, is a complex and multifunctional nerve that plays a crucial role in various physiological and psychological processes. Here’s a breakdown of its functions and the potential benefits of stimulating it:

## Functions of the Vagus Nerve
- The vagus nerve is the longest cranial nerve, extending from the brainstem (medulla oblongata) down to the abdomen, passing through the neck, thorax, and into the abdominal organs[1][4][5].
- It is a key component of the parasympathetic nervous system, often referred to as the "rest and digest" system, which helps to calm the body and counteract the "fight or flight" response of the sympathetic nervous system[1][4][5].
- The vagus nerve provides motor parasympathetic fibers to most organs from the neck to the second segment of the transverse colon, influencing heart rate, gastrointestinal peristalsis, and other visceral functions. It also controls some skeletal muscles involved in swallowing, speech, and other functions[1].
- Approximately 80-90% of the fibers in the vagus nerve are afferent, meaning they carry sensory information from the body's organs to the central nervous system, providing continuous feedback about the state of the body's viscera[1][5].

## Benefits of Vagus Nerve Stimulation
- **Digestion**: Stimulating the vagus nerve can indeed influence digestion by enhancing gastric emptying and stimulating acid production in the stomach[1][5].
- **Heart Rate and Blood Pressure**: The vagus nerve helps regulate heart rate and blood pressure through its parasympathetic influence, which can help lower these parameters when they are elevated[1][4].
- **Anxiety and Mental Health**: There is substantial evidence that vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) can have positive effects on mental health conditions such as depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). VNS has been shown to reduce symptoms of depression, including postpartum depression, and can help regulate inflammation, which is often associated with psychological illnesses[2][4][5].
- **Inflammation**: The vagus nerve has anti-inflammatory properties, and stimulating it can help reduce chronic inflammation, which is beneficial for various inflammatory conditions[2][5].
- **Weight Management**: Studies have shown that VNS can help in weight management by delaying gastric emptying and enhancing the release of anorexigenic hormones, leading to reduced food intake[3].
- **Other Benefits**: VNS has also been used to treat epilepsy, aid in stroke rehabilitation, and reduce symptoms of opioid withdrawal. It can help in stress recovery and improve overall well-being by promoting a calm state and reducing the body's stress response[2][3][4].

## Is Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Effective?
The scientific evidence supports the efficacy of vagus nerve stimulation for several medical and psychological conditions. While some claims on social media might be exaggerated or lack specific scientific backing, the core benefits of VNS are well-documented in clinical research.

- For medical conditions, VNS is approved by regulatory bodies like the FDA for treating depression, epilepsy, and other conditions[2][3].
- Non-invasive methods to stimulate the vagus nerve, such as deep breathing, physical exercise, and certain meditation practices, can also be beneficial for general well-being and stress reduction[4][5].

In conclusion, stimulating the vagus nerve is not "bullshit" but rather a scientifically supported therapeutic approach with a range of potential benefits, particularly in the areas of digestion, mental health, and inflammation management. However, it is important to consult healthcare professionals for personalized advice and treatment, especially if you are considering VNS for a specific medical condition.

173.question: i was diagnosed when i was young with a seizure thing that goes away when youre 13, which impairs my ability to concentrate and gave me seizures while im sleeping about once every blood moon and my mom told me it was epilepsy, but see the thing is that shes not very good with english, and i have never had any trouble with seeing flashing lights. is it possible to have epilepsy but no trouble with seeing flashing colors?
173.answer:
Yes, it is entirely possible to have epilepsy without experiencing visual disturbances such as seeing flashing colors or lights. Epilepsy is a broad term that encompasses various types of seizures, each with different symptoms depending on the part of the brain affected.

Here are some key points to consider:

## Types of Seizures
- **Focal Aware Seizures (FAS):** These seizures, previously known as simple partial seizures, can involve a wide range of symptoms, including motor symptoms like lip-smacking, chewing movements, or repetitive jerking, and non-motor symptoms such as déjà vu, unusual smells or tastes, or a rising feeling in the stomach. Visual disturbances are not a universal symptom[1][3][5].

## Specific Lobe Seizures
- **Temporal Lobe Seizures:** These can involve feelings of fear, anxiety, déjà vu, or unusual smells and tastes, but not necessarily visual disturbances[3][5].
- **Frontal Lobe Seizures:** These often involve motor symptoms like thrashing or bicycling movements of the extremities, particularly during sleep, without necessarily involving visual symptoms[3].

## Absence Seizures
- While some seizures can involve visual disturbances, absence seizures typically do not. They are characterized by a brief loss of awareness, often with staring and sometimes blinking, but no significant visual symptoms[3][4][5].

## Your Specific Case
- If you experienced seizures primarily during sleep and had issues with concentration, it could be related to a form of epilepsy that does not involve visual disturbances. The fact that your seizures occur about once every "blood moon" (which is not a medical term but could imply a rare or periodic occurrence) suggests a specific type of epilepsy that may not include visual symptoms.

Given the variability in epilepsy symptoms, it is plausible that you have a form of epilepsy that does not involve seeing flashing colors or lights. A thorough medical evaluation, including electroencephalogram (EEG) tests and a detailed history of your symptoms, would be necessary to determine the exact type of epilepsy you might have.

Shortly after I had my new iud put in I started having issues with my left eye, vision became blurry”ish” on and off. For the next 3 weeks I Had slow thought processing during the time & some confusion. - Hard time finding words. I also had some “left neglect” symptoms but that’s normal for me when I get migraines because my left side goes numb so I related all of this to stress & the migraines until I started having muscle twitching in my left hand & wrist. - I started to improve end of March but My vision is still off sometimes & I’m not as sharp as I used to be. I Had an eeg in April which showed slowing, which I feel like is normal.. but I just had a follow up MRI & this is the report.. is someone able to explain it to me? No one has ever told me I had radiation necrosis. I guess I was always under the assumption my brain would heal itself after my radiation… but 4 years later it just seems to be getting worse. Does radiation necrosis heal/is it dangerous? Could this just be swelling? Did is progress fast from January 2022-April 2023? 4.. Since I’m not getting blood flow there is it basically the same thing as a ischemic stroke? What is FLAIR hyperintensity? Those are just questions off the top of my head. I don’t see a dr until June and google is not my friend.
174.answer:
Radiation necrosis (RN) of the brain is a complex and challenging condition, and its progression and treatment options are not straightforward.

### Healing and Progression of Radiation Necrosis

Radiation necrosis is generally considered a serious and often irreversible condition, although some cases can show improvement with treatment.

- **Irreversibility**: Traditionally, RN was viewed as a progressive and irreversible condition. However, recent studies suggest that some cases can be managed and even improved with various treatments[3][5'.
- **Treatment Outcomes**: Studies have shown that treatments such as hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT), bevacizumab, and other interventions can lead to clinical and radiological improvements in some patients. For example, HBOT has been shown to improve oxygenation in affected brain tissues, reduce swelling, and enhance neurological function[1].
- **Variability in Response**: The response to treatment can vary widely among patients. Some may experience significant improvements, while others may not show much change or may even worsen[1][5].

### Symptoms and Diagnosis

The symptoms you are experiencing, such as blurry vision, slow thought processing, confusion, and muscle twitching, can be indicative of radiation necrosis, especially given your history of gamma knife treatments.

- **FLAIR Hyperintensity**: FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) hyperintensity on MRI is often associated with radiation necrosis. It indicates areas of brain tissue damage and edema, which can result from the radiation-induced vascular injury and disruption of the blood-brain barrier[3][5].

### Comparison to Ischemic Stroke

While radiation necrosis is distinct from an ischemic stroke, both conditions involve tissue damage due to different mechanisms.

- **Radiation Necrosis**: This condition is caused by radiation-induced vascular injury, leading to tissue necrosis and edema. It does not involve an acute blockage of blood flow like an ischemic stroke but rather a gradual process of tissue damage[3][5].
- **Ischemic Stroke**: This is caused by the sudden blockage of blood flow to an area of the brain, leading to rapid tissue ischemia and necrosis.

### Swelling and Edema

Swelling and edema are common in radiation necrosis due to the disruption of the blood-brain barrier and increased vascular permeability.

- **Edema Management**: Treatments like glucocorticoids (e.g., dexamethasone) are commonly used to control edema associated with radiation necrosis. Other treatments, including HBOT and anti-VEGF therapy, can also help reduce swelling and improve symptoms[1][3][5].

### Conclusion

Given your symptoms and the findings on your MRI, it is possible that you are experiencing radiation necrosis. Here are some key points to consider:

- **Seek Medical Consultation**: It is crucial to discuss your MRI results and symptoms with your doctor to get a definitive diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.
- **Treatment Options**: Depending on the severity and your overall health, your doctor may recommend treatments such as HBOT, bevacizumab, or other interventions to manage your symptoms and slow the progression of RN.
- **Monitoring**: Regular follow-up with your healthcare provider is essential to monitor the progression of the condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

Until you see your doctor in June, it might be helpful to keep a detailed record of your symptoms and any changes you notice, which can aid in your medical evaluation.

He has been having increasing seizures in the last 7 years, and the neurologist just ups his meds. December of last year he had a big one. I had to call an ambulance because his active seizure was over 15 minutes. He stayed in a postectal state for over 5 hours. They did a CT scan, and it shows an area of calcification, and his neurologist said that is normal and unchanged.What I have noticed is that before his more major seizures, he will have a bad headache that advil or tylenol will not touch. Then a few hours later, he will have a seizure that will last between 3-5 minutes, with a postectal state ranging from 10 minutes to an hour.Is this something that can even be fixed or managed better? Is it just part of living with someone with epilepsy?
175.answer:
The scenario described involves several complex factors that influence your husband's epilepsy and seizure management. Here are some key points and potential considerations:

## Headaches and Seizures
The headaches your husband experiences before his seizures are not uncommon. Headaches can be closely linked to seizures, and they can occur at various times relative to the seizure:
- **Pre-ictal headaches**: These occur before a seizure and can be a warning sign. Studies have shown that headaches, especially migraine-like headaches, can precede seizures[2][5].
- **Post-ictal headaches**: These occur after a seizure and are also common[2][5].

## Triggers and Risk Factors
Several factors can increase the frequency and severity of seizures, some of which may be relevant to your husband's situation:
- **Sleep Deprivation**: This is a known risk factor for increased seizure frequency. Ensuring adequate sleep could help manage seizures[1][4].
- **Head Injuries**: While your husband had a significant surgical intervention 15 years ago, any subsequent head injuries could still impact his seizure frequency[1][4].
- **Depression and Mental Health**: The use of anti-depressants suggests that mental health is being managed, but ongoing monitoring and adjustment of mental health treatment may be necessary to minimize its impact on seizure frequency[1][3].

## Medication and Treatment
- **Anti-Epileptic Drugs (AEDs)**: The neurologist's decision to increase the dosage of Tegretol (carbamazepine) is a common approach to manage increasing seizure frequency. However, it might be beneficial to discuss other treatment options or adjustments, especially given the severity and duration of some seizures[1][3].
- **Medication Adherence**: Ensuring consistent adherence to medication can significantly impact seizure control. Factors like substance use (though your husband does not use substances) and mental health issues can affect adherence[1][4].

## Seizure Duration and Postictal State
- **Status Epilepticus**: A seizure lasting over 15 minutes, as in your husband's case, is a medical emergency known as status epilepticus. This condition can lead to brain damage or other severe complications. Close monitoring and prompt medical intervention are crucial[3].

## Additional Considerations
- **Surgical and Neurological History**: The separation of hemispheres (hemispherectomy) 15 years ago is a significant surgical intervention. Any changes or calcifications seen on CT scans should be closely monitored, even if they are deemed normal and unchanged. Regular follow-ups with the neurologist are essential to adjust treatments accordingly.
- **Lifestyle and Environmental Factors**: Keeping track of any triggering factors such as noise, light, or stress can help in managing seizures better[4].

## Management and Improvement
To better manage your husband's seizures:
- **Seizure Diary**: Keeping a detailed diary of seizures, including any pre-ictal symptoms like headaches, can help identify patterns and potential triggers.
- **Regular Neurological Follow-Ups**: Continuous monitoring by a neurologist is crucial to adjust medications and other treatments based on the evolving needs.
- **Lifestyle Adjustments**: Ensuring adequate sleep, avoiding known triggers, and maintaining good mental health can help reduce the frequency and severity of seizures.
- **Support and Education**: Being informed about epilepsy and its management can help both you and your husband cope better with the condition.

180.question: Hi! So basically, my question is already in my headline. I've got elevated eosinophil levels, my neurologist explained it as though my body is fighting a parasite, but without me having a parasite. I have an appointment with a hematologist in June, but I was wondering if anyone here could have an idea what this means. I'm currently on 250mg of Topamax, 2mg of Rivotril and 225mg of Venlafaxine. Thank you. Update: According to my doctor, normal eosinophil levels are up to 8%, mine are 22%. I have no allergies and I haven't been abroad.
180.answer:
Elevated eosinophil levels, as in your case, can be indicative of several underlying conditions, even if there is no actual parasite infection. Here are some key points to consider:

## Causes of Eosinophilia
Eosinophilia, which is defined as an eosinophil count of more than 500 cells per microliter of blood, can be caused by a variety of factors. Common causes include:
- **Allergic disorders**: Such as asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis, and drug allergies. However, you mentioned you have no allergies[2][3][5].
- **Parasitic infections**: Although your doctor mentioned no actual parasite, this is often a common cause. Since you haven't been abroad, this is less likely[2][3][5].
- **Cancers and blood disorders**: Conditions like Hodgkin lymphoma, leukemia, and certain myeloproliferative neoplasms can cause eosinophilia[1][2][5].
- **Autoimmune diseases**: Such as inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis), autoimmune myocarditis, and vasculitis[3][5].
- **Other medical conditions**: Including eosinophilic esophagitis, eosinophilic asthma, and hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES)[1][3][5].

## Hypereosinophilic Syndrome (HES)
Given your high eosinophil count (22% which translates to a significantly elevated absolute count), HES is a possibility, although it is more common in older men. HES is characterized by an eosinophil count of more than 1,500 cells per microliter of blood for more than 6 months without an obvious cause. It can lead to organ damage, particularly affecting the heart, lungs, liver, skin, and nervous system[1][2][4].

## Symptoms and Diagnosis
Often, people with mild eosinophilia may not have symptoms, but high levels can cause inflammation and damage to various organs. Since you are asymptomatic aside from concerns related to your epilepsy medications, it is crucial to determine the underlying cause. Your hematologist will likely conduct additional tests, including biopsies if necessary, to rule out other conditions and confirm the diagnosis[1][2][3].

## Impact of Current Medications
While your current medications for epilepsy could have various side effects, it is less likely that they would directly cause such a significant elevation in eosinophils. However, it's important to discuss all your medications with your hematologist to rule out any drug-related causes[2][3].

## Next Steps
Given your upcoming appointment with a hematologist, here are a few things to expect:
- **Further testing**: To determine the underlying cause of the eosinophilia, including tests for infections, autoimmune diseases, and cancer.
- **Biopsies**: If tissue eosinophilia is suspected, biopsies may be necessary to examine the affected organs.
- **Treatment**: Will depend on the underlying cause. For example, if an allergic reaction or medication is the cause, stopping the offending agent may resolve the issue. If it's due to a more serious condition like HES, treatment may involve corticosteroids, chemotherapy agents, or other targeted therapies[1][2][3].

It is important to follow up with your hematologist and provide them with all the details about your medical history, current medications, and any symptoms you might be experiencing.

## Inflammation and Epilepsy

There is substantial evidence suggesting a strong link between inflammation and epilepsy. Here are some key points:

1. **Brain Inflammation**: Chronic brain inflammation, involving the activation of microglia, astrocytes, and the production of inflammatory mediators, is thought to be a crucial mechanism in the pathophysiology of seizures and epilepsy. This inflammation can lead to changes in neuronal excitability and enhance seizure-induced neuropathology[1].

2. **Seizure-Induced Inflammation**: Seizure activity itself can induce brain inflammation, and recurrent seizures can perpetuate this chronic inflammation. This process involves the upregulation of inflammatory mediators such as IL-1β, the complement system, and adhesion molecules[1].

3. **Immune System Activation**: The involvement of the immune system, including the activation of peripheral immune cells and the expression of chemokines, can recruit more inflammatory cells into the brain, contributing to the epileptogenic process[1].

Given your history of Crohn’s disease, which is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) characterized by chronic inflammation, it is plausible that systemic inflammation could exacerbate or contribute to the development of epilepsy.

## Cysts and Inflammation

The presence of cysts throughout your body could be related to inflammation in several ways:

### Inflammatory Bowel Disease and Extraintestinal Manifestations

1. **Crohn’s Disease**: While Crohn’s disease primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract, it can have extraintestinal manifestations, including various types of cysts. For instance, ovarian cysts are more common in patients with IBD compared to the general population, although the difference may not always be statistically significant[5].

2. **Systemic Inflammation**: The systemic inflammation associated with Crohn’s disease can lead to a variety of extraintestinal complications, including the formation of cysts in different parts of the body. This is part of the broader spectrum of immune and inflammatory responses seen in IBD[2].

### Specific Types of Cysts

1. **Inflammatory Radicular Cysts**: These cysts, which are not directly related to your condition but illustrate the role of inflammation, form as a result of chronic inflammatory processes, involving the activation of immune cells, the release of pro-inflammatory interleukins, and the proliferation of epithelial cells. Similar mechanisms could be at play in other types of cysts that form in an inflammatory context[3].

## Clinical Implications

Given the interconnectedness of inflammation in your conditions:

- **Monitoring and Management**: It is crucial to manage your Crohn’s disease effectively to reduce systemic inflammation, which may in turn help in managing your epilepsy and potentially reduce the formation or growth of cysts.
- **Interdisciplinary Care**: Coordination between your gastroenterologist, neurologist, and other specialists is essential to address the various aspects of your conditions comprehensively.
- **Targeted Therapies**: Considering the role of inflammation in both epilepsy and cyst formation, therapies targeting inflammatory pathways might be beneficial. This could include anti-inflammatory medications or immunomodulatory treatments[1].

Consulting with your healthcare providers to integrate a holistic approach to managing your chronic inflammation, epilepsy, and cysts could be highly beneficial in improving your overall health and reducing the severity of your symptoms.
